awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Emergent properties governing robustness in regulatory networks important for cell, tissue, and organ function
awd_abstract_narration:
Plants are critical for all aspects of human life as the primary source of food, fiber, shelter, and fuel. Game-changing advances are needed for plant engineering to effectively and sustainably increase crop production and meet the demands of a growing population. Regulation of plant growth and biomass is dependent on the continuous generation of stem cells that differentiate to form all the cells, tissues, and organs of the plant. Understanding the spatial and temporal control of stem cell self-renewal and their differentiation is critical for generating predictable outcomes and redesigning plants for our future needs. At present, it is known that groups of cells differentiate and display functions in response to positional information, and those local cell-to-cell interactions drive cell-specific gene expression patterns. However, interrogating cellular reprogramming has thus far been limited by the challenge of manipulating individual cells. This EAGER award will lead to the development of novel technological advances that will enable the direct study of plant cell characteristics during organ formation.  This project will combine interdisciplinary and convergent research training for postdocs, graduate, and undergraduate students. It will be coupled with professional development by means of established and ongoing outreach activities (i.e., including a summer internship for underrepresented minority undergraduates) to build the skill sets needed for tomorrow’s workforce.


This research, exploiting 3D bioprinting, quantitative image analysis, and single-cell transcriptomics, will address the following question: What are the emergent system-level characteristics involved in cell-to-cell communication, patterning formation, and robustness that instruct cell identity and differentiation during plant organ formation? Accordingly, by combining 3D bioprinting with single-cell transcriptomics, this proposal will offer an innovative approach to study the minimal cues, positional effects, and signaling pathways key for plant developmental processes such as cell identity or differentiation in single cells. This research will broaden the understanding of how various signals are integrated with robust developmental programs, and this gained knowledge that could lead to the discovery of new patterns and forms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to explore how plant cells communicate and coordinate during development, with a focus on understanding the rules that govern stem cell identity, differentiation, and system robustness. By integrating advanced technologies such as 3D bioprinting, quantitative imaging, and single-cell transcriptomics, this research provides new insights into the spatial and temporal dynamics of cell interactions in plants.

Intellectula Merit

1. Development of 3D Bioprinting Techniques We successfully optimized 3D bioprinting protocols for plant cells, allowing us to recreate cellular architectures mimicking natural plant tissue. These techniques involved fine-tuning bioprinting parameters such as protoplast generation, scaffold composition, extrusion pressure, and needle gauge. For example, we found that low extrusion pressures (20-35 kPa) and specific scaffold materials, like low-melting agarose and Pluronic hydrogels, maximized cell viability. These findings provide a foundation for creating anatomically accurate and functional plant tissues in the lab.

2. Insights into Cell Viability and Communication Our studies revealed that cell walls in bioprinted plant cells reform within five days, a critical milestone for re-establishing structural integrity and enabling symplastic communication—the exchange of molecules between neighboring cells. Using fluorescent probes and advanced imaging techniques like Raster Image Correlation Spectroscopy (RICS), we tracked the movement of small molecules and proteins, such as SHORTROOT (SHR), a key regulator of vascular development. These experiments demonstrated how environmental conditions, such as phosphate availability, influence cell-to-cell communication.

3. Transcriptional Dynamics of Bioprinted Cells We developed and applied an RNA extraction protocol to analyze gene expression in bioprinted cells over time. By identifying differentially expressed genes (DEGs) related to stress responses, cell communication, and metabolic adjustments, we gained insights into how cells adapt to bioprinting and environmental stressors. These findings highlight the influence of scaffold materials and nutrient environments on cellular behavior and gene regulatory networks.

Broader Impacts

Advancing Agricultural Biotechnology This research provides tools and knowledge that can be applied to agricultural biotechnology, such as developing crops with improved stress resilience and nutrient use efficiency. For example, understanding how plant cells communicate and adapt to environmental conditions could inform strategies for engineering plants that thrive in nutrient-poor soils.

Educational and Professional Development The project trained four postdoctoral researchers, fostering the next generation of scientists. These researchers gained expertise in cutting-edge technologies, including 3D bioprinting, transcriptomics, and quantitative imaging. Additionally, the project supported interdisciplinary collaboration between plant biologists and engineers, promoting the integration of diverse scientific perspectives.

Scientific Publications Key findings were disseminated through peer-reviewed publications and preprints, including:

  • Establishing a reproducible approach for the controllable deposition and maintenance of plants cells with 3D bioprinting (Science Advances, 2022)

  • Tissue Regeneration with Hydrogel Encapsulation: A Review of Developments in Plants and Animals (BioDesign Research, 2022)

  • Cell-Material Interactions in 3D Bioprinted Plant Cells (BiorXiv, 2024)

  • Advancing Plant Science Through Precision 3D Bioprinting (Current Opinion in Biotechnology, in press)

These publications acknowledge the support of the NSF Career Grant and contribute to the growing field of plant tissue engineering.

This project represents a significant step forward in understanding plant cell communication and development. By leveraging 3D bioprinting and single-cell transcriptomics, we uncovered fundamental principles of cell identity, tissue patterning, and environmental adaptation. These insights have broad implications for both basic plant science and practical applications in sustainable agriculture, contributing to innovations that address global challenges in food security and environmental resilience.


 


Last Modified: 01/07/2025
Modified by: Rosangela Sozzani
